note_text:
Admission Date:  [**2163-2-9**]              Discharge Date:   [**2163-2-14**]

Date of Birth:  [**2101-4-18**]             Sex:   F

Service: NEUROSURGERY

Allergies:
Shellfish Derived / Peanut

Attending:[**First Name3 (LF) 1835**]
Chief Complaint:
Newly diagnosed brain mass, h/o breast CA

Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
NONE


History of Present Illness:
Pt. is a 61 y/o female with a hx of breast CA s/p mastectomy,
chemo, radiation, who is transferred from an OSH for further
work
up of a newly diagnosed brain mass.
Pt. is intubated and sedated and no family is available.
History from chart.
From report EMS was called because of dyspnea.  When they
arrived
they found patient awake/confused, not oriented, and unable
to provide history,  They transferred her to an OSH.  Head CT
was
performed and showed a L occipital lesion.  LFTs were somewhat
elevated on labs (AST 43, AP 269) but S tox was negative.  She
vomited twice while she was there.  Then at 21:30 she had a
seizure. She received 10 mg Valium, then 1 g Dilantin.  She was
intubated and transferred for further eval.


Past Medical History:
She has metastatic breast cancer,s/p Left mastectomy, XRT, chemo
arthritis, and hypertension. She does not have diabetes, COPD,
or
hypercholesterolemia.


Social History:
 She was smoking 1 pack of cigarettes per week for 4 years. She
does
not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Her brother lives in the
city
near her and a son lives in [**Name (NI) 4444**], MA.


Family History:
Her maternal grandfather had [**Name2 (NI) 499**] cancer while
her paternal grandfather had stomach cancer. Her mother died of
[**Name (NI) 2481**] disease while her father passed away after a stroke.
Her brother and sister are healthy, and so are her four
children.


Physical Exam:
Physical Exam on discharge:
T:  BP: 148/68,  HR:77 NSR    R 14 vented  O2Sat100%
Gen: WD/WN, s/p L.mastectomy
HEENT: Pupils:3-2mm EOMI
Lungs:CTA
Chest: left mastectomy noted.
Cardiac: RRR. S1/S2. no obvious murmur
Abd: Soft, NT, BS+
Extrem: Warm and well-perfused.
Neuro:
A/A+Ox3, PERRLA @[**4-3**],EOMI, face symmetric, tongue midline, no
pronator drift, MAE [**6-6**], +fing-nose coordination, speech
clear/fluent.

Toes downgoing bilaterally


Pertinent Results:
[**2163-2-12**] 03:06AM
WBC  RBC   Hgb   Hct   MCV MCH   MCHC   RDW   Plt Ct
9.6  3.35* 10.0* 28.6* 85  30.0  35.1*  13.4  285

Glucose UreaN Creat   Na  K    Cl   HCO3  AnGap  Phenyto
 91      17    0.6   137  4.1  100   29   12      9.4

Sinus rhythm. Normal tracing. No previous tracing available for
comparison.


Read by: [**Last Name (LF) **],[**First Name3 (LF) 900**] A.

  Intervals Axes
Rate PR QRS QT/QTc P QRS T
90 144 88 378/430 33 0 29


PROCEDURE: Chest portable AP radiograph. Procedure performed on
[**2-10**], [**2163**].

COMPARISON: Compared to [**2163-2-9**] examination.

HISTORY: 61-year-old woman with occipital mass. Evaluate NG tube
after being placed.

FINDINGS: The NG tube projects and terminates in the left upper
quadrant and then courses inferiorly and to the right with
distal tip not viewed on this study. Otherwise, the lungs are
clear. The heart is unremarkable. No pleural effusion is noted.

IMPRESSION: 1) Feeding tube distal tip is not visualized on this
chest radiograph; out of view.

MR HEAD W & W/O CONTRAST  [**2163-2-10**] 12:32 AM
IMPRESSION: Multiple enhancing lesions of varying sizes
throughout the brain, the largest in the left occipital lobe and
the left frontal lobe. The pons and right cerebellar hemisphere
are also involved. These are consistent with metastatic disease
and the location of these lesions increases the likelihood of
leptomeningeal disease.

CT HEAD W/O CONTRAST  [**2163-2-9**] 2:35 AM
IMPRESSION:
1. Probable metastatic lesion within the [**Doctor Last Name 352**]-white matter
junction of the left occipital lobe with surrounding vasogenic
edema. MRI is recommended for further evaluation of this lesion
including evaluation for cryptogenic lesions.
2. Probable left frontal extra-axial meningioma.


Brief Hospital Course:
61-year-old right-handed woman with a diagnosis of breast cancer
in [**2162-4-1**], s/p chemo-irradiation, and had a seizure on [**2163-2-9**].
Her boyfriend called 911 and the ambulance came and took her to
a local
hospital. She vomited twice while she was there. Then at 21:30
she had another seizure. She was given Valium and then Dilantin.
She was intubated and was transferred to [**Hospital1 190**]. Head CT was performed and showed a left
occipital
lesion. Subsequent head MRI showed multiple enhancing lesions in
the brain. Liver functions were somewhat elevated on labs (AST
43
and alkaline phosphatase 269).

No surgical intervention was required. Pt was medically managed
with follow up plan for whole brain radiation therapy, which she
will receive close to her home in [**Location (un) 2251**]. Plan discussed and
agreed upon with patient.
She was seen by PT OT.  Radiation oncology was consulted - a
treatment plan is to be determined as the pt would like to go to
an outside facility.


Medications on Admission:
unknown

Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: 1-2 Tablets PO Q6H (every 6
hours) as needed.
2. Lisinopril 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).

3. Metoprolol Tartrate 25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO TID
(3 times a day).
4. Levetiracetam 500 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO BID (2
times a day).
Disp:*120 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
5. Dexamethasone 4 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q8H (every 8
hours).
Disp:*90 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*


Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service

Facility:
All Care VNA of Greater [**Location (un) **]

Discharge Diagnosis:
LEFT OCCIPITAL, CEREBELLAR, PONTINE BRAIN Mets / H/O BREAST CA


Discharge Condition:
NEUROLOGICALLY STABLE


Discharge Instructions:
??????	Have a family member monitor your symptoms
??????	Take your pain medicine as prescribed
??????	Increase your intake of fluids and fiber as pain medicine
(narcotics) can cause constipation
??????	Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, aspirin, Advil,
Ibuprofen etc.
??????	If you have been prescribed an anti-seizure medicine, take it
as prescribed and follow up with laboratory blood drawing as
ordered
??????	Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at
your post-operative office visit

CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE
FOLLOWING:

??????	New onset of tremors or seizures
??????	Any confusion or change in mental status
??????	Any numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities
??????	Pain or headache that is continually increasing or not
relieved by pain medication
??????	Fever greater than or equal to 101?????? F


Followup Instructions:
PLEASE CALL [**Telephone/Fax (1) **] TO SCHEDULE AN APPOINTMENT WITH
DR.[**Last Name (STitle) **] at [**Telephone/Fax (1) **]   / neurosurgery to be seen in 4 weeks
YOU WILL NEED A CAT SCAN OF THE BRAIN

You should call the brain tumor clinc at [**Telephone/Fax (1) **] for follow
up of your radiation planning/schedule

you should call your primary care physician to be seen in two
weeks to notify them of your hospitalization and changes to your
medication
